rangees.data: Stabilizer of the longitudinal plantar arch
Intersection of plantar fascia and anterior aspect of calcaneus inferior border

content.subtitle: Subject Positioning
text: The feet can be allowed to hang over the end of the table (more comfortable position)
Alternatively, for increased stress on the plantar structures (including the fascia), the feet can be placed on the bed, resting on the toes (thus with the ankle positioned at a right angle)

content.subtitle: Anatomical Landmarks and Palpation
text: Locate and palpate the calcaneus and the metatarsal heads

vues.title: Longitudinal View
objectifs: Monitor the effect of therapeutic interventions
positionnement: Place the probe on the anterior end of the calcaneus, along the long axis of the foot, slightly medial to the midline
It is then possible to scan distally along the foot to follow the course of the plantar fascia (medial portion), ensuring to keep it within the field of view (due to its triangular shape)

texte: The calcaneal head appears as a circular area with a hyperechoic margin in the lower left quadrant of the image
The origin of the plantar fascia is located just at the surface of the calcaneal head, on the left of the image, and appears as a triangular hyperechoic area with visible striated organization
The plantar fascia is located to the right of its origin and displays the same echogenicity and texture as its origin
The flexor digitorum brevis muscle is located beneath the plantar fascia as a thick, slightly hyperechoic area
The inferior surface of the calcaneus is located beneath the flexor digitorum brevis muscle. It is recognizable by the cortical bone which appears as a long horizontal hyperechoic margin
Below the Achilles tendon and to the left of the calcaneus is Kager's fat pad, which appears as a disorganized triangular hypoechoic area

text: Unlike the skin covering the dorsal region of the foot, the skin covering the plantar surface is thick, with an epidermis approximately eight times thicker than that of the dorsal surface [1]. At the posterior aspect, the skin covers a very thick subcutaneous tissue (plantar fat pad, average thickness of 18 mm) whose most obvious role is the absorption of impacts inherent to locomotion. Additionally, it has a recognized function as a static and dynamic stabilizer of the longitudinal arch [6].

The plantar fascia is a fibrous connective tissue that can be divided into three sections (or 'cords'): central, lateral, and medial. The central portion, which is our focus, connects the calcaneus (medial tubercle) to the metatarsophalangeal joints (separating into 5 bands at the midtarsal level), and can be directly observed through ultrasound and magnetic resonance imaging. This portion of the plantar fascia has a triangular shape (wide posteriorly, narrow anteriorly) and stands out as being the thickest, widest, and strongest of the three cords.

From a functional and clinical perspective, the correlation between the plantar fascia and the triceps surae (gastrocnemius and soleus) is well established, but the anatomical foundations of this correlation were not/little known until recently. A study published in 2013 [8] established that the plantar fascia is connected to the paratenon of the Achilles tendon (not the tendon itself) through the calcaneal periosteum. This supports the idea that the triceps surae tends to be involved in pathologies involving the plantar fascia. Furthermore, the results of this study suggest that the lateral and medial portions of the plantar fascia could be a source of proprioceptive afferents involved in motor coordination, which is of particular interest in a rehabilitation context.

From a clinical physiotherapy perspective, the interest in the plantar fascia can be explained in part by its structure's tendency to change with certain mechanical stresses. These structural modifications can affect, for example, the thickness or stiffness of the plantar fascia [11] [See 'Clinical Relevance' section]. Also, as is the case for many other joints, plantar fascia ultrasound can be used for injection guidance, to avoid injection into the plantar fat pad, which would result in adipose tissue atrophy (and incidentally reduces the number of injections needed) [9].

content.subtitle: Evaluation of plantar fascia thickness vs presence of plantar fasciitis
text: An excellent systematic review published in 2014[6] evaluated more than thirty articles dealing with the management of plantar fasciitis using ultrasound imaging.

The current state of scientific literature suggests that the evaluation of plantar fascia thickness using ultrasound imaging is an effective and valid method for the diagnosis and monitoring of plantar fasciitis.

From a metrological quality perspective, ultrasound is comparable in several aspects (reliability, validity) to magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and thus represents a very interesting option for clinicians given its high accessibility. Moreover, when compared to conventional radiography and MRI, ultrasound imaging is less expensive, faster, simpler to use, less invasive, and radiation-free.

Finally, the difference in plantar fascia thickness (healthy population vs. with plantar fasciitis) was found to be statistically significant (p < 0.0005), indicating that this data can be considered clinically significant[10].
